moves.3. c3 Nf6 4. d4: Instead of defending you attack, a perfectly good strategy.
moves.4... exd4 5. e5: Pressing the attack.  This will help you develop your position without sacrificing material.  Good strong opening.
moves.5... Qe7 6. Qe2 Nd5 7. Na3 dxc3 8. e6: This pawn was safe where it was.  Now it isn't.
moves.8... Qxe6 9. Ng5: Now I am encouraged to swap queens, strengthening that three pawn advantage.
moves.12... Bxg5 13. Nd4: Better yet would be BxPg7, making back a point while breaking up the black king's pawns.
moves.14... O-O 15. O-O Nf4 16. Rfe1 Re8 17. B: Oops, this gives black white's white bishop.  Bc4 would have been better.
moves.17... Nxe2+ 18. Kf1: If black moves the knight black loses the game with RxRe8#.
moves.18... d5 19. g3 Bd7 20. Rxe2: White should have taken the knight before the black bishop could pin white's rook against his king.
moves.20... Bb5 21. h4: Nice response, threaten something else.  In this case the reprieve is only temporary.
moves.21... Bxe2+: Rook is worth more than bishop, but the check saves it.
moves.23. Rc1 Bxc3 24. Rxc3 c6 25. Rc2: White decides to gang rape the a2 pawn.
moves.25... Bc4 26. g4 Re2 27. Rc3 Rxa2 28. Rf: White wonders if he will have a second chance to play pin the rook on the king.  Probably not.
moves.28... d4 29. Rf4: Not. Good to pressure the pawn, though.
